item.title: OpenTalk No.89 | AI Twin Brain： Model Training, Evaluation, Application
item.description:
分享嘉宾:



刘泉影，南方科技大学长聘副教授，博导，PI。2010年/2013年毕业于兰州大学信息学院，获学士/硕士学位。2017年于瑞士苏黎世联邦理工学院获博士学位，其后在美国加州理工学院从事博士后研究工作。2019年8月回国，在南方科技大学成立神经计算与控制实验室（NCC lab）。主要研究方向是多模态神经信号处理算法、脑网络动力学建模、神经编解码算法、神经调控优化算法等工作，致力于从人工智能、控制理论和脑科学交叉融合的视角，发展基于AI的多模态神经解码算法，构建数据驱动的AI孪生脑模型，研发智能化的闭环神经调控系统，推动“读出-写入”双向脑机接口技术的发展，为解码脑功能和干预神经疾病提供全新范式，已在Nature Methods、The Innovation等期刊，NeurIPS、ICML、ICLR等机器学习顶会上发表论文60余篇。

item.title: Registration for the COSN Summer Hackthon in 2025
item.description:
The COSN Summer Hackathon is back again!!! Through the three events from 2022 to 2024, more and more participants have had the opportunity to participate in the Hackathon. This year’s Hackathon will be themed “AI + Brain Science”, focusing on the exploration and application of artificial intelligence technology in the field of brain science. Everyone is welcome to propose relevant projects (the specific submission process will be announced later)! “Learning through doing” or learning through practice is the spirit of the Hackathon.

This Hackathon will provide you with:

  1. Opportunities for communication with scholars in the fields of neuroscience, cognitive science and artificial intelligence;
  2. The chance to interact with experienced programming experts in the neuroscience field and advance one’s research projects;
  3. The opportunity to establish connections with like-minded friends and explore future collaborations;
  4. Exploring the unlimited possibilities of the integration of AI and brain science;
  5. The chance to learn about open science and repeatable research, among others.

Click the link to register (https://www.wjx.cn/vm/tYCvkf3.aspx).

item.title: OpenTalk No.86 | The Academic Impact of Open Science
item.description:
分享嘉宾:


Thomas Klebel is a member of the Open and Reproducible Research Group and a Senior Researcher at Know Center. In his research, he investigates unintended consequences of current implementations of Open Research, ways of improving the reproducibility of research findings, and avenues for sustainable business models around open research infrastructure. With a focus on quantitative methods of inquiry, he is also keenly interested in causal modelling and ways of improving research practice. Thomas completed his doctoral studies in Sociology in 2024 and holds a degree in Music Performance from the University of Performing Arts Graz. You can find him on ORCID and LinkedIn.

item.title: Exclusive interview with the editor-in-chief of eLife
item.description:
Exclusive interview with the editor-in-chief of eLife: Without the impact factor, the number of submissions from China has decreased by 80%

In November 2024, Clarivate announced that the eLife journal would no longer be assigned an SCI impact factor. Previously, this interdisciplinary biology journal had an IF of 6.4. As of 2025, this pioneering open-access journal began to feel the aftershocks of losing the impact factor, and “the biggest and most significant changes all came from China.”

Dr. Timothy Behrens, the editor-in-chief of eLife, is the deputy director of the Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging at the University of Oxford, a professor of computational neurobiology, and an honorary lecturer at University College London. He disclosed to the intellectuals: “(Before the decision of Clarivate Analytics)”, “About 40% of the submissions to eLife came from China. Now, we have lost approximately 80% of the submissions from China.”

This non-profit academic journal was established in 2012 and is supported by three powerful scientific funding institutions in the United States (Howard Hughes Medical Institute), the United Kingdom (Wellcome Foundation), and Germany (Max Planck Society). The founding editor was Randy Schekman, a 2012 Nobel Prize winner. eLife is renowned for its pioneering and experimental publishing model. After winning the Nobel Prize, Randy Schekman publicly criticized top journals such as CNS (Cell, Science, Nature), saying they were like “limited luxury goods”, causing unnecessary pressure on scientists.

From its inception, in addition to open access, another significant innovation of eLife was the collaborative system for peer review, which means that the reviewers and the editors discuss the opinions together. This concept attracted dozens of active scientists to serve as editors, responsible for screening the submissions, and hundreds of scientists to serve as reviewers.

item.title: New Publication | "Robustness Report Journal" in Diamond Open Access Model
item.description:
This week, a brand-new open-access diamond journal - the Journal of Robustness Reports (abbreviated as JRR) - officially launched (website: https://scipost.org/JRobustRep). This journal focuses on publishing brief re-analyses of published empirical research results.

The majority of empirical research papers only report a single main analytical result, which is usually carried out by a single analysis team (often also the team responsible for the experimental design and data collection) according to a single analysis plan. However, the “multi-analyst projects” in recent years have shown that different analysis teams often adopt their own unique methods, resulting in significant differences in conclusions. In fact, there is no single optimal statistical analysis plan, and different reasonable plans may lead to different conclusions. The strong variability of conclusions indicates their vulnerability, which is highly dependent on the specific analysis path. The key issue is that without independent analyses by multiple teams, it is difficult to assess the robustness of the conclusions. We recently proposed that for empirical research with significant scientific or social significance, 2-3 short reanalysis reports completed by independent experts should be attached [1]. To verify the feasibility and cognitive value of this method, we established the “Robustness Report Journal”, dedicated to publishing reanalyses of empirical results. This article outlines the journal’s positioning, workflow, and article format of JRR. We hope that JRR can promote reanalysis to become a routine practice in the field of empirical science.

JRR requires that the main body of the “Stability Report” should not exceed 500 words (excluding acknowledgments, references, chart explanations and title page). Only one presentation element (either a figure or a table) is allowed, and other supplementary materials must be presented in the form of online appendices. The response from the original author and the editor’s summary are also limited to 500 words and one presentation element, but they do not need to follow the above chapter structure. The article template is available in both Word and LaTeX versions.

The original intention behind setting the word limit: JRR hopes to encourage mainstream empirical journals to adopt this format, attaching robustness reports to important studies – a 500-word length is comparable to that of a “comment” or “letter to the editor” (most journals are already familiar with such formats), and the implementation cost is extremely low.
